review.title: Challenges in Bridging Social Semantics and Formal Semantics on the Web
review.abstract: This paper describes several results of Wimmics, a research lab which names stands for: web-instrumented man-machine interactions, communities, and semantics. The approaches introduced here rely on graph-oriented knowledge representation, reasoning and operationalization to model and support actors, actions and interactions in web-based epistemic communities. The re-search results are applied to support and foster interactions in online communities and manage their resources.

Nice Sophia Antipolis, CNRS, I3S, UMR 7271, 06900 Sophia Antipolis, Francefabien.gandon @ inria.frAbstract.This article describes several results of Wimmics, a research laboratory that stands for web-based human-machine interactions, communities and semantics. The approaches presented here are based on graph-oriented knowledge representation, argumentation and operationalization to model and support actors, actions and interactions in web-based epistemic communities.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction: toward hybrid societies on the web
sections.text: The web is no longer perceived as a documentary system. Among its many developments, it has become a virtual place where people and software interact in mixed communities, i.e. a hybrid space where people and web robots interact and form new types of collectives, which we will call hybrid societies here. These large-scale interactions create many problems, especially those of reconciliation of formal semantics of informatics (e.g. logic, ontologies, typing systems, etc.) on which the web architecture is built, with soft semantics of people (e.g. posts, tags, status, etc.) on which the web content is built. Let's take a concrete and very common example. Many websites include forums, blogs, status feeds, wikis, etc. In other words, many websites incorporate content management systems and quickly build huge collections of information resources. As these collections grow, several tasks become more difficult to automate: search, notification, navigation aid, etc.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Wimmics provides models and algorithms to bridge formal semantics and social semantics by formalizing and arguing heterogeneous semantic graphs. Models we design include: users, their profiles, their requirements, their activities, and their contexts; social links, social structures, social exchanges, and processes; conceptual models, including ontologies, thesauri, and folksonomies. Whenever possible, these models are formalized and published in accordance with standardized web formalisms, and can motivate research and proposals to expand these standards. Schemes and datasets created are published as linked data that follow the principles of web architecture; the algorithms we study include: typed graphs that index, argue, and seek; hybrid processing that merge logical conclusions, rules, and metric conclusions; approximation and dissemination algorithms become distributed and scalable alternatives to classical argumentations.
